summary_strategy: Position Conner as a security engineer who builds and operates production-grade DLP systems—not just policy designers—highlighting his automation-first approach, endpoint hardening expertise, and experience translating compliance requirements into deployable controls
skills_strategy: Use the condensed 3-line format to emphasize Security Engineering & Automation, Cloud/Platform Integrations (highlighting Microsoft Graph API and CrowdStrike RTR), and Security Data & AI (emphasizing asset correlation, Pandas/NumPy analytics, and RAG governance), all aligned with DLP operational needs

experience_focus.must_highlight: endpoint hardening automation, API-driven security workflows, compliance-to-controls translation
experience_focus.safe_metrics_to_keep: 10,000+ devices managed, 200 hours saved annually, 500 hours reduced workload, 25 percent compliance improvement, 30 percent reduction in user-reported issues
experience_focus.claims_to_avoid: no invented metrics, no unverified tool claims (e.g., Zscaler/Qualys), no hypothetical policy design without evidence of implementation

risk_controls: Do not add tools or responsibilities not explicitly supported in baseline resume or analysis mapping
Never fabricate metrics—even if implied—unless directly quoted from source material
Avoid phrases like 'designed for compliance'; instead use 'translated requirements into deployable controls' or 'operationalized standardized asset remediation'
Replace speculative DLP-specific claims with evidence-based parallels: e.g., 'BitLocker enforcement across 10,000+ devices' instead of 'implemented DLP policies'
Do not mention Zscaler, Qualys, or Jira unless explicitly stated in resume; use Defender XDR and Rapid7 only where documented
